candidates.title: final changes for 0.8.0
candidates.body: With links updated and FAQs extended all that remains should be updating the website.

candidates.title: 0.8.0-rc1
candidates.body:
Changes from rc0
- Removes HasTwo
- makes `dimensions` take a non-mutable reference
- `logical_size` in WindowMode
- adds support for zip compression
- makes `request_quit` into a context method instead of an event mod function 
- adds missing deprecated functions
- canvas screen coords now equal their size
- export glam
- fix src scaling issue (removes `image_scale` and restores 0.7 behavior)
- updates dependencies
- removes srgb parameter
- bzip2 feature has been renamed to zip-compression
- split text bounds, layout and wrapping
- make `last_delta` and `set_modifiers` public
- move InstanceArray's `ordered` parameter into a separate constructor called `new_ordered`

----------------------

- [x] Note that updating a dep to a breaking version (i.e., nalgebra 0.13 -> 0.14) is a BREAKING API CHANGE and should not be done on things that don't break API. For instance, we screwed this up 'cause ggez 0.4.0 used nalgebra 0.13 and 0.4.1 used nalgebra 0.14... so this broke the exposed API. (Doing this for packages that aren't publically exposed is PROBABLY okay...)
- [x] Fix all rustc warnings
- [x] Make sure all unit tests pass
- [x] Test all examples
- [x] Read all docs (ideally in rendered form)
- [x] Also read (and ideally test) all docs and guides inside the docs folder! (check that links are up to date, etc.)
- [x] rustfmt
- [x] clippy
- [x] Search for and remove all expect() and unwrap() calls
- [x] Search for and address all TODO and BUGGO comments

candidates.title: Add logical_size to WindowMode and use it when set to add DPI aware window sizing
candidates.body:
- Fixes https://github.com/ggez/ggez/issues/1091

The default width/height ggez uses is converted into a winit's PhysicalSize and used in two places:
  - The WindowBuilder for creating the window initially
  - set_window_mode which is called shortly after the window is first shown (1 frame from what I can tell)

This works great, except on high DPI machines, where 800x600 is exceptionally small.

winit has a LogicalSize which is correctly scaled by the current screen's DPI. However, as we do not want to break the common/easy case of width/height, it is being added as a optional argument on WindowMode (width/height is ignored when set to Some).

To add this to WindowMode, winit must include the serde feature as WindowMode is marked Serialize.

Usages of `dpi::PhysicalSize` that access conf.width/conf.height are now incorrect, so I added a crate public to create actual_size on WindowMode to prevent duplication.

One error case in resizing has been converted into an assert for simplicity, it only appears to be possible if the Window is set to a larger than 1x1 size and then resized to 0x0.

candidates.title: Use subcontexts directly instead of free functions
candidates.body:
Deprecates the old free functions and uses the subcontexts directly, as mentioned in #1012 and discussed in the Matrix room. WIP.

Note: The graphical context hasn't been refactored since the changes would be overwritten by the WGPU PR anyways.

candidates.title: Update dependencies
candidates.body:
- `winit` to `0.26`
- `glutin` to `0.28`
- `directories` to `4.0`

**Please only open PRs that are based on and aimed towards the `devel` branch**

**For more information take a look at [the contribution guide](./CONTRIBUTING.md)**

candidates.title: Added an example showcasing animation with keyframe
candidates.body:
Based on the discussion in #910 I finally made an example showcasing both tween and frame-by-frame animations using keyframe.

It... works, but there's some code duplication, that I'd really like to get rid off.
But after fiddling with generics for some time I now think the only option would be to use macros to do that, but I'm unsure as to whether we'd want to do that, since we probably don't want to force new (Rust) users to read macro code in order to understand the example.

But maybe I'm missing something.

candidates.title: Everyone think we're good to make this RC2?
candidates.body: This commit just updates the Cargo.toml and such.

candidates.title: Fixes canvas being upside down
Bump lyon to 0.17.5
candidates.body:
Relies on https://github.com/ggez/ggez/pull/917 so that CI succeeds.

* The `basic_shapes` module was removed as described [here](https://github.com/nical/lyon/issues/606), so most of the changes are related to using `FillTesselator` and `StrokeTesselator` instead.
* `BasicVertexConstructor` was also removed, meaning that the only way to add vertices to `BufferedBuilders` is as part of a stroke or fill. The only place where that API was relied on was in `MeshBuilder.triangles`, so I just inserted the vertices directly into the `VertexBuffers`.

chosen_pr.title: Bump lyon to 0.17.5
chosen_pr.body:
Relies on https://github.com/ggez/ggez/pull/917 so that CI succeeds.

* The `basic_shapes` module was removed as described [here](https://github.com/nical/lyon/issues/606), so most of the changes are related to using `FillTesselator` and `StrokeTesselator` instead.
* `BasicVertexConstructor` was also removed, meaning that the only way to add vertices to `BufferedBuilders` is as part of a stroke or fill. The only place where that API was relied on was in `MeshBuilder.triangles`, so I just inserted the vertices directly into the `VertexBuffers`.

chosen_detail.title: Bump lyon to 0.17.5
chosen_detail.body:
Relies on https://github.com/ggez/ggez/pull/917 so that CI succeeds.

* The `basic_shapes` module was removed as described [here](https://github.com/nical/lyon/issues/606), so most of the changes are related to using `FillTesselator` and `StrokeTesselator` instead.
* `BasicVertexConstructor` was also removed, meaning that the only way to add vertices to `BufferedBuilders` is as part of a stroke or fill. The only place where that API was relied on was in `MeshBuilder.triangles`, so I just inserted the vertices directly into the `VertexBuffers`.
